productivity: Agroforestry increases productivity and farmers’ incomes from a diversified production system with food security benefits.
adaptation:
Promotes soil and water conservation. [2]
Reduces erosion, land degradation and vulnerability to climate shocks, increased soil stabilization and water infiltration rates.[3]
mitigation: Increased above- and below-ground biomass from agroforestry increases carbon stocks in the soil and reduce soil C losses from erosion. [3]
b1_exp: Farmers lack training for the practice
name: James Giles

productivity:
Increased crop productivity by 20-30% [3]
Increased net profits of 22% compared to conventional production [4]
Decreases cost of digging tubewells by 40% [2, 3]
20-25% less seed required [3]
adaptation:
Water saving up to 30-50% [1,2]
Reduced water stress
Reduced crop lodging 
Better drainige during heavy rains
mitigation: Higher nutrient use efficiency, reducing fertilizer requirement
b1_exp: Farmers lack information on the benefits
b2_exp: Labour intensive
name: James Giles

productivity:
Net income of 15,030 PKR/Year with three animals [1]
Healthy goats can yield 1-3 liters of milk a day [1]
mitigation: Manure can be used as a source of organic fertiliser
b1_exp: Farmers lack training for the practice
name: James Giles

productivity:
Increased yields by 10% [1]
14% more profitable than conventional practices [2]
adaptation:
Water saving upto 20% [1]
Increased water-holding capacity and decreased soil loss via erosion [2]
Can decrease soil salinity (when using saline toleran variaties) [2]
mitigation:
Increases organic matter in soil [2]
Reduced fertilizer input costs [2]
Nitrigen added to soil through nitrogen fixation [2]
b1_exp: Labour intensive
b2_exp: Farmers unaware of benefits
name: James Giles

productivity:
The water- and soil-conserving effects of CA help to stabilize or increase yields against weather extremes and in the long term. 
CA also reduces costs associated with tillage, whether manual or by machinery by 15-20% in Malawi [1]. 
The reduction in field preparations with CA also allows timelier planting, which supports successful harvests [1]
adaptation:
CA increases soil water content by increasing infiltration and reducing runoff and evaporation thus improves water use efficiency and buffers crops against drought. 
Mulch cover also buffers the soil against temperature extremes. 
Reducing tillage and maintaining soil cover with crop residues can reduce erosion by up to 80%. [1]
CA also generally increases soil organic matter in topsoil, as well as soil biological activity and biodiversity.
mitigation: CA practices can mitigate climate change by increasing carbon sequestration in the soil.
b1_exp: Farmers lack training for the practice
name: James Giles

productivity:
30% more profitable than conventional transplanting [5]
Increase yield by 160-200 kg per acre [2]
Reduced cropping period by approx. one month [2]
Give 20-25% more plant population [2] 
Labor saving
Allow timely planting of subsequent crop due to early harvest [2]
adaptation:
Water savings by 15-30% [1,2]
Deeper root growth, more tolerance to water and heat stress [1]
mitigation: Reduced methane emission [1]
b1_exp: Higher costs for production
b2_exp: Younger farmers are more likely to adopt, older farmers are more accustomed to the conventional method
name: James Giles

adaptation: 30% less water used [2]
mitigation: 48% reduction in methane emissions [2]

productivity: Crop rotation increases total production and productivity per unit area of land. Harvests of multiple crops from this system increase farmer’s income and food security.
adaptation: This practice reduces the risk of total crop failure due to diversification of crops under climatic shocks. Improves soil fertility. Rotating crops maintains soil fertility and minimizes the incidence of pests and diseases.
mitigation: The practice of crop rotation helps to protect soil structure, increases soil organic matter and organic carbon reserves. Leguminous species integration reduces the need of synthetic fertilizers. When combined with nitrogen fixation species (leguminous) reduces the use of nitrogen-based synthetic fertilizers.
b1_exp: Farmers lack training for the practice
name: Nam Nguyen

Progressive reduction of lime application
can be achieved through inclusion of
organic matter/fertilizers, enhancing
biological activity and subsequently soil
fertility
mitigation:
In combination with organic fertilizers
improves soil carbon stocks and organic
matter content, hence reducing gradually
the use of synthetic fertilizers and
associated GHG emissions.
